author: Katie Amey for MailOnline
title: Colorado's Stanley Hotel that inspired Stephen King's The Shining may build horror museum
text:
View
comments
What's the only thing scarier than the hotel that inspired Stephen King's best-selling bone-chilling tale, The Shining?
That same hotel with its very own horror-themed museum, of course.
Just in time for Halloween, The Stanley Hotel in Estes Park, Colorado, which served as King's inspiration behind his 1977 classic, has just announced that it is planning to add a building housing a museum, film production studio and film archive.
The Stanley Hotel in Estes Park, Colorado, inspired Stephen King's writings of the Overlook Hotel in his horror classic, The Shining
The landmark hotel is located near the entrance to the state's Rocky Mountain National Park and is seeking $11.5 million (almost £7.5 million) in Colorado tourism funds.
Plans for the Stanley Film Center, the name organisers are hoping to give it, include a 599-seat auditorium, museum, room for travelling film exhibitions, a sound stage and a post-production and editing space.

It would operate as a nonprofit public-private partnership, reports the LA Times , and would partner with the Colorado Film School in Denver on some projects.
However, the plans are all dependent on the state's approval. The government is expected to make a decision in December.
Although the Stanley Hotel did not feature in the 1980 film, The Shining, the set did take inspiration from the site
Now, the hotel is looking to further capitalise on his spooky history by adding a horror-themed museum, auditorium, film production studio and film archive
The 109-year-old hotel is full of eerie features, which makes it the perfect location to inspire such a scary story
Before the proposed project can get underway, however, the state government will need to approve millions in funding
'At 109 years old, the story of the Stanley Hotel is just beginning,' hotel owner John Cullen told Inquisitr . 'The Stanley Film Center is my chance to give back to the millions of horror fans around the world who have supported Estes Park and the hotel for so many years.'
As the model for the Overlook Hotel in The Shining, this isn't the first time that the hotel has capitalised on its spooky history - it also offers seasonal ghost tours and hosts a horror film festival.
And of course, The Shining plays on loop on one of the TV channels in each room, no matter the time of year.
